RUSSIA.2. Full details of the recent Police searchThe PoliceSearch of"Arcos".(previous reference:Cabinet 17(27), Con-c conclusion 4".)(This Con-clusion was kept inmanuscriptand notcirculated.)of "Arcos" and of the Russian Trade Delegation(situated in the same building, in which thepremises of the two organisations had beenfound to be so mixed that it was impossible to differentiate between them) were presented tothe Cabinet in the form of alternative drafts of the statement which the Home Secretary had undertaken to make in the House of Commons thesame afternoon.Stress was laid on the importance of avoid-ing any indication of the identity of theindividual on whose information the search hadbeen undertaken. The possibility was indicated that further information might be availabletowards the end of the week.The Cabinet agreed (a) That a statement should be madethe same afternoon in the Houseof Commons to the effect thatthe information which had comeinto the possession of the Policeas the result of the search of"Arcos" was of such a nature thatit had not been found possible forHis Majesty's Government to com-plete its examination or todetermine the consequences of it,and that for this reason they must ask the permission of the House ofCommons to postpone the full state-ment until next Tuesday:(b) That a Cabinet Committee, composed as follows The Lord Chancellor,The Secretary of State forForeign Affairs,The Secretary Of State for home Affairs,The Secretary of State for India,. The Secretary of State for War,The Chancellor of the Duchy of lancaster,The Attorney-General,Sir Maurice Hankey (Secretary) should meet to prepare, for con-sideration by the Cabinet, astatement for Parliament on-3- -4-a basis read to the Cabinet bythe Foreign Secretary. It wassuggested that, at the discretion of the Lord Chancellor, this statement might be communicatedto the Cabinet orally.(e) That the Secretary of State forDominion Affairs should send atelegram to the Dominions to theeffect that the information obtained in the course of the search of "Arcos" was of so gravea character that the Cabinet attheir next Meeting might have to sanction a statement of such a nature as might result in theremoval of"the Russian trade delegation from London.(d) That the Cabinet should hold aSpecial Meeting on MONDAY next,MAY 23rd, for the purpose of considering the Report of theLord Chancellor's Committeeand the questions of policy involved therein. PORTUGAL.Request forpossibleAssistanceat Macao.3. The Cabinet had before them a Memorandumby the Secretary of State for Foreign affairs in regard to a reqinest from the portuguese government for assistance at Macao in certain eventualities. In this Memorandum the bearingof the ancient Treaties with Portugal on this request are discussed (Paper CP.-155 (27)).In the course of the discussion attention was drawn to the ill-treatment accorded inrecent years to British traders by thePortuguese Government. The Cabinet were reminded that the Portuguese Government had entered into an agreement for repayment oftheir war debt.The Cabinet agreed That the Secretary of State forDominion Affairs should beauthorised to inform the governor of Hong-Kong of the nature ofthe request made by the portuguese government and to authorise him.,in the event of the Governor ofMacao calling upon him for military or naval assistance to meet a sudden and serious emergency, torender him such assistance as hecan without further referencehome, on the strict understandingthat the Governor is satisfiedthat the requirements of his ownColony can be fully met. TheSecretary of State was asked to emphasize that His Majesty'sGovernment did not like torefuse the request, but that heshould only intervene in a reallyserious situation. 4. The Cabinet had before them the following documents relating to the arms embargo and thesupply of arms to Canton:-A Note by the Secretary of Statefor Foreign Affairs covering aMemorandum prepared in the ForeignOffice in which the view is expressed that we should adhere to our policy of neutrality amongthe contending Chinese factions(Paper CP.-156 (27)):A Letter from the Colonial Officeto the Foreign Office, to be readin conjunction with the above(Paper CoP.-157 (27)).Attention was called to Telegram No. 35of May 16th. from Mr Brenan (Canton) reporting that he had made certain demands on General LiChai-sum in consequence of the action of theCommander of the Whampoa Forts in firing on aBritish merchant ship. The Cabinet were reminded that General Li Chai-sum is the same person towhom it had been proposed (in the Papers underconsideration) to give facilities for obtainingarms .Attention was also drawn to a telegramfrom Sir Miles Lampson, No. 846, of May 11th, .on the subject of Major Nathan's proposedindustrial loan to Chang Tso-lin, the effect ofwhich had been that Major Nathan had undertaken to telegraph to Mr Waley Cohen0 in London, asking him to consult the Foreign Office on that question.The Cabinet agreed (a) As regards the arms embargo, thatthe policy of neutrality among thevarious contending factions inChina should be adhered to, andthat no facilities in the matterof arms should be given to the, Cantonese General LI Chai-sum:(b) That if Mr Waley Cohen should visit the Foreign Office, he should be . informed that His Majesty'sGovernment were not concernedin any private loan which he might make to any party inChina, but he should be warned that he could not expect toreceive any support by force or otherwise, in collectingthe interest on the loan. 9 S*5. The Cabinet were informed that the China(Military Details) Committee had decided onFebruary 28th (G.M.O. (27) 1st Conclusions)that sufficient troopships should be keptbetween Hong-Kong and Shanghai to enable a brigade to be on the water simultaneously at.short notice and at the minimum expense. Underthis decision three ships were at present-retained. The five transports conveying the15th Brigade were now arriving at Hong-Kong,and the Secretary of State for War proposedthat these should be dispensed with as soon asthe troops are landed. To retain them in theFar Bast, would cost approximately 1,400 a day.The 15th Brigade might not have to move from hong-Kong, and if a move became necessary itcould be carried out by the ships alreadyretained.The Cabinet authorised theSecretary of State for war to continue to act on the. decision of the China(Military Details) committee referred to above. 9 0CHINA.The Retentionof the IndianMixed Brigade.(previous reference e:Cabinet 18(27), Con-elusion 7 .)6. In connection with the subject dealt within the previous Conclusion, the Cabinet were informed that,if there were any question of returning the Indian Mixed Brigade to India,a saving of perhaps 100,000 would be effected by sending it back in.the ships which had brought the 15th Brigade to Hong-Kong.The Cabinet were reminded that considerable expense was involved in the retention of theIndian Mixed Brigade.The Cabinet agreed That until the situation in Chinabecame clearer than at present it would be unsafe to dispense with the presence of the "IndianMixed Brigade of the ShanghaiDefence Force. 2/17. The Cabinet had before them a Memorandumby the Minister of Labour proposing action on adraft Convention concerning the simplificationof inspection of emigrants on board ship, andin regard to a recommendation concerning theprotection of emigrant women and girls on board ship (Paper C.P.-153 (27)).The Cabinet agreed (a) That the Government shouldregister its ratification ofthe draft Convention concern-ing the simplification of the inspection of emigrants onboard ship, with the proviso that it should only become effective on ratification byPrance, Germany, Holland, Italy,Norway and Spain:(b) That the recommendation concern-ing the protection of emigrantwomen and girls on board ship.should be accepted, and that innotifying our acceptance weahould inform the InternationalLabour Office in general terms as to the British law and practice,and state that it is proposed tocontinue to give women and girlemigrants on board British ships the same protection as at present. 11.
